title: The Revelation of Jesus Christ in Scripture
subject: Theology

document.title: Doctrinal Elements of a Curriculum Framework for the Development of Catechetical Materials for Young People of High School Age

0B7F82CB56D7498598758162CF4831F9.description:
In modern times, there are individuals and groups
who try to explain in natural scientific terms the
miracles of Jesus, thus undermining his divinity.

127ADD6B04904C06BC29A5DCC6664D01.description:
Sometimes people did not like what Jesus taught or
did or what happened to him. There were a number
of “gospels” written, which the Church, under
the guidance of the Holy Spirit, recognized as not
authentic. Some of these gospels shied away from
teaching the Incarnation, suffering, Death, and
Resurrection of Jesus.

85BBB656AFBC42998A1D351A80E2C0D2.description:
In the early history of the Church, there were a
number of heresies about Jesus Christ which arose
when people tried to explain the mystery of who he
was and is. An example of this is the Arian heresy,
which denied the full divinity of Christ.

A1FE389FA7FC4399BCCB202B925F6C71.description:
People have tried to change teaching about
Christ for many different reasons. Sometimes it
is to justify their particular belief or lack of belief.
Sometimes it has been out of sincere but misguided
or misinformed efforts to try to explain mysteries
about Jesus Christ or God’s Revelation.

A5120BDB4F9C41DC9B742EA0714CA2E9.description:
Why do some people try to change what the Church
teaches about Jesus Christ?

D4FC277908B244B5AC0681DE0B1433B1.description:
Apostolic Tradition refers to those things that
Jesus taught to the Apostles and early disciples,
which were passed down to us at first by word
of mouth and were only written down later. We
identify these beliefs as coming from Tradition
and understand that this Tradition is part of God’s
Revelation to us (CCC, no. 83).

333F1F5B5FB849118C15AF0FD679345B.description:
There are teachings that come through Tradition
that are not explicitly found in Scripture. However,
nothing taught through Tradition ever contradicts
Scripture since both come from Christ through the
Apostles (CCC, no. 82).

34E1E5609A33480797752203575235F3.description:
The Bible is not the sole means that God chose
to hand on the truths of Revelation. Scripture
and Tradition are the two complementary ways
Revelation is passed down (CCC, nos. 80, 97).

482C9F89870243D0B963946181BBEA29.description:
Why do Catholics maintain beliefs and practices that
are not in the Bible?

CC1C72286C664E5D93897FF3370DFE01.description:
God continues to speak to us through Scripture;
this is why the liturgies of the Church always
contain Scripture and why personal prayer focused
on Scripture is vital.

4ED02777C70846CA97E893890134DCE4.description:
While the Bible contains history, stories, and
teaching about events in the past, Scripture is the
living Word of God. While the content is rooted
in particular moments in history, the message is
timeless and universal.

7D8415E6426E4ABCA5545264A2265E9C.description:
Isn’t the Bible about the past? Why do people today
think it applies to them?

BA28588E3E5E43F09A082E63A660450C.description:
The Church gives guidelines for interpretation of
Sacred Scripture (see earlier in outline).

47861E4A6FAB4656A710AEE91A6C8A9E.description:
The Bible has a definite historic basis for events
recounted in both the Old and the New Testaments;
the Church particularly upholds the historicity of
the Gospels (CCC, no. 126). However, the Church
does not claim that the Bible’s purpose is to present
scientific or historical facts (CCC, no. 107).

981E80FCCEF54396B6FE54AE2D0CE6FA.description:
It depends on what one means by “literally.” The
Church does not always propose a literalist or
fundamentalist approach to Scripture but rather a
contextualist approach. The Church teaches that
all of Scripture is true on matters pertaining to
religious and salvific teaching because it is inspired
by God for that purpose (CCC, nos. 107, 116).

6694B878C508498286CDAD77B618CE0B.description: Is the Bible always literally true?

923E21101EE945058C809356A9901056.description:
Scripture always needs to be read or interpreted in
the light of the Holy Spirit and under the direction
of the Church (CCC, nos. 100, 111, 119, 137).

D4D30FE1C0A64C0795A12DBB65277EC2.description:
Since it is not just another piece of literature,
Scripture cannot be either read or understood
merely in the same way as other literature (CCC,
no. 108).

C387BDE696A9493E9941E73C991E7D2D.description:
No. While Scripture contains various types of
literary forms and genres, it is more than just
literature. It is the inspired Word of God (CCC, no.
135).

87526E4929E743D496276E68B1F3A773.description: Isn’t the Bible just another piece of literature?

533F43C7F97740E195DBF8F2F37EF1EB.description:
In the fourth century, St. Jerome said that
“ignorance of the Scriptures is ignorance of Christ”;
this underlines the importance of Scripture in the
life of the Church (CCC, no. 133).

AF69CFDC0F8B4FCF8BCE33C51100FC0D.description:
Scripture study and prayer groups using Scripture
are a common part of parish life.

C3810C82A5C54781872B5311ACD5A105.description:
The Church urges Catholics to use the Bible in
personal prayer (CCC, nos. 2653-2654).

CF325D9A98CE46D2B2C67E928E80E1F6.description:
No. Catholics use the Bible regularly. The Bible
or Scripture is an integral part of Catholic prayer
life, forming part of every Mass, every sacramental
celebration, and the official daily prayer of the
Church—the Liturgy of the Hours (CCC, nos.
141, 1190).

858EF5FD8E0149308E12618E7E2C66C7.description: Is it true that Catholics do not use or read the Bible?

B8B1E1EA53AF409FB154625247627166.description:
Christ’s Last Supper discourse and priestly
prayer.

D6FA4B56E4CB4A59BE84593AC81B0F3F.description: John treats miracles as signs of Christ’s glory/divinity—flows from John 1:14.

229A0BEB1A1F4C918F99A223A86AC723.description:
John uses Christ’s dialogues and personal
testimony and is more mystical (CCC, nos.
547-550).

DF063A4F25E5472BBE77102941F118F9.description: The content of the Gospel of John.

5CCDF71C24864EDCA750B1C104A20665.description:
Approximate date of the Gospel and churches for
which John wrote.

E406181948424DF693FE4EBA1B6BDD39.description:
Last Supper, the Passion, Death, Resurrection,
Ascension (CCC, nos. 1329, 1337, 1366,
1323, 1412, 1521-1522, 1532, 1708, 1992,
2020).

3521ABDD35D444A8B276D6E4FF3932DF.description:
Sermon on the Mount in Matthew; Sermon on
the Plain in Luke.

B03EB3B3DF77482E929F0F43F7590C54.description: Infancy narratives in Matthew and Luke.

2A4AFB1AAA7F4050A3B85A2679D1AF05.description:
The contents of the Synoptic Gospels (CCC, nos.
512-667).

C05C3A5FBB1F4473927CF2827538CF19.description:
The churches for whom Matthew, Mark, and
Luke wrote.

651EB4DADBD049DB9B0CEADE91CCE795.description:
What is known about each of these three
evangelists.

4E94DA1165E84316B7CED7EFB7FE6E61.description: The Synoptic Gospels: Matthew, Mark, and Luke.

C95774A835B7421E91E32AE7E88808D4.description:
Three stages in the formation of the Gospels (CCC,
no. 126).

DD06CBB986AA4720884833CC09030770.description:
The Gospels lead us to accept Jesus Christ in faith
and apply his teachings to our lives.

B8EF7440F81D431DAD87DA7D34908C28.description:
The Gospels contain a record of the life of Jesus
Christ and of his teachings and redeeming work.

C663BB7B77354BD19ECF4C182E2C4ABB.description:
They proclaim the Good News of Jesus Christ, the
Word of God, the definitive Revelation of God.

D438A6AEF7CF4E508FA4B63E8D6BB39C.description:
The Gospels occupy the central place in Scripture
(CCC, nos. 125, 139).

2ACACDDC4D874E3BA8362BAFE35850BA.description:
The unity of the Old Testament and the New
Testament (CCC, nos. 124-125, 128-130, 140).

4EC4CA27F8644441AD1264FB94D864EF.description:
The New Testament is composed of the Gospels,
the Acts of the Apostles, the Epistles or Letters,
and the book of Revelation.

3F87EFB7901747C4B86355164590529B.description:
This is the name given to those twenty-seven
books which compose the second part of the Bible
and which focus on the life and teachings of Jesus
Christ and some writings of the early Church.

151D2FF387EE460C97F2E9CEDB3DAF84.description:
The Old Testament contains the Pentateuch,
the Historical books, the Wisdom books, and the
Prophetic books.

674296A2BA6A49268D2419BFF406E777.description:
It is called the “Old” Testament because it relates
God’s teaching and actions prior to the coming of
Jesus Christ, who is the fullness of Revelation. It
also focuses on the covenant God made with the
Jewish people, which is called the “Old Covenant”
to distinguish it from the New Covenant made by
Jesus Christ (CCC, nos. 121-123).

B252F0AD5ADB4CA09C23FA2D5ABCB0E9.description:
Catholics rely on the Greek version of the Old
Testament for their Bible, while Protestants
tend to rely on a Hebrew version.

61103727018C486FA0BC9C90F058A801.description:
Many Protestant Bibles have only thirty-nine
books in the Old Testament; other Protestant
Bibles contain the additional seven, referring
to them as “deuterocanonical.”

3CD91FA4D08248048CF166F600374FAB.description:
This is the name given to the forty-six books which
make up the first part of the Bible and record
salvation history prior to the coming of the Savior,
Jesus Christ (CCC, no. 120).

BB442935A15A4A9A8BD629F6FA6D16CE.description: The forms of literature in the Bible.

1DAC1F58B0744DDCB851A6591EDB91CD.description:
Biblical archaeology: discoveries of Dead Sea
Scrolls, Nag Hammadi, targums, and other
authentic ancient texts.

70E441289AA743D1AFE8DA6C39A98260.description:
Research done by scholars’ critiques of Scripture’s
texts, history, editing, etc.

E9105352B46F43F99FA2207AC8A58DD1.description:
The difference between the Catholic understanding
of Scripture and that of those who interpret
the Bible in an overly literalist, fundamentalist
way or with an approach limited to a symbolic
understanding.

87966DC26F344AE6BCF9001D4209BA2E.description:
There can be no conflict between religious truth
and scientific and historical truth (CCC, no. 159).

2588CB37F9D14802BA7ABFB9D1BBD0C7.description:
The Church teaches us how to relate truths of faith
to science.

7D812911360C47869B29CA5390EDE477.description:
The Bible in relation to science and history (CCC, nos.
37, 159, 1960).

D7694957793240F2801B6222163ACCF3.description:
Anagogical sense: Scripture speaks to us of
eternal realities.

B2772AF7F2C144BD8358D1A96A292E86.description:
Moral sense: Scripture teaches us and
encourages us how to live and act.

29A4A44304BF44D09F2DFA4F7C4A775E.description:
Allegorical sense: recognizing the significance
of events in the Bible as they relate to Christ.

5E297F625C8E478B80C0D817CF0DACF6.description:
The literal sense: the meaning conveyed by the
words of Scripture and discovered by exegesis
(CCC, nos. 109-110, 116).

75B8141DAA4643D5B57FC858E0B09C46.description:
Be attentive to the analogy of faith, that is, the
unity that exists in all Church teaching.

9AB3F368786A4EA8B54D3011CB9974A8.description:
Read and interpret each part of Sacred Scripture
with an awareness and understanding of the unity
of the content and teaching of the entire Bible.

E5047BACD92D484E9B8729E376FD7D83.description:
Read and interpret Sacred Scripture in the light
of the same Holy Spirit by whom it was written
(DV, nos. 12-13).

790E464F870B4B758EBACEBB13A4F272.description:
Take into account the conditions of the time when
it was written and the culture where it was written.

81F7B51E6D1A4DFBBCEF528C42A5AE16.description:
Give attention both to what the human authors
intended to say and to what God reveals to us by
their words.

4B208506A39E4376B6882D445ACA3678.description:
Read and interpret Sacred Scripture within the
tradition and teaching of the Church.

44C2975DA6BB42469C5746024C7B1584.description:
Criteria for interpreting the Sacred Scripture (CCC,
nos. 109-114, 137).

21ED14511FB646E091409F071D4EF675.description:
Pontifical Biblical Commission, Interpretation of the
Bible in the Church, 1993, nos. 5-19.

22936957741B4F8198A7F992B206C98A.description:
Dei Verbum (DV) (Vatican II, 1965; Church
teaching on Revelation).

E462A12D594A4624A836603DFDB104E7.description:
Divino Afflante Spiritu (Pius XII, 1943; permitted
limited use of modern methods of biblical
criticism).

FE29A87F3BDD4331B58F029CA7B8EEFE.description:
Authentic interpretation of the Bible is the
responsibility of the teaching office of the Church
(CCC, nos. 85-87, 100).

5B424B2D2FD94CF9B10B7966990D1884.description:
Scripture as basis for individual prayer and for
prayer within small Christian communities and
other parish, school, or local gatherings (CCC,
nos. 2653-2654).

24E06AE02A1E4479AB24A400CE38960B.description:
Lectio divina: a meditative, prayerful approach
to Scripture (CCC, nos. 1177, 2708).

FE55CE98A64A4A3A98D23F358A3DF9A9.description:
The psalms and the Our Father are biblical
prayers shared by all Christians (CCC, nos.
2585ff., 2759ff.).

54FE269718184F88BB1156A0186B6907.description:
Scripture at Mass and other liturgies (CCC,
nos. 103, 1096, 1100, 1184, 1190, 1349).

A37441F9CCAC4A1184F189A20EDE2797.description: Sacred Scripture in the life of the Church.

C53785F42767495BBC58424275BF0565.description:
Local Councils of Hippo (AD 393) and
Carthage (AD 397).

2CF3BA4B44084E27A2838A707141DB7D.description:
Sometimes other criteria came into play, e.g.,
the Gnostic gospels were rejected in part
because they did not include or shied away
from the suffering and Death of Jesus.

CB6BECA07CC245BDA427CBCD7040B427.description:
Apostolic Tradition is the basis for which
books
the Church included (CCC, nos. 120, 138).

3B5F32758AA346CEBEDCA6BCDA2D6FBC.description: Setting the canon of Scripture (CCC, no. 120).

76079C87151543528185775CE66DED23.description:
Development of the written books (CCC, nos.
76, 106).

3A889D7AD33E4A8B8B2AB9DC2F947DAD.description: Oral tradition and its role (CCC, nos. 76, 126).

EA1A1926FE534CE1BFA92DD612F82E73.description: How the Bible came to be.

552C7E2075014117A506332BCFB46CC5.description:
The Bible is a sacred text for Christians; it contains
in the Old Testament writings sacred to the Jews.

F2FEAB47234246A5A964B14686D83122.description:
The Bible is inerrant in matters of Revelation
and faith: because God is the author of Scripture, all the religious truths that God intends to reveal
concerning our salvation are true; this attribute is
called “inerrancy” (see DV, no. 11; CCC, no. 107).

F53EDB51697745E8A704118127B8ACB5.description:
Because the human authors needed to use the
language and thinking of their time, we need to
study the conditions and use of language in the
context of their time and understand what they
intended to communicate, remembering that these
human authors might not have been conscious of
the deeper implications of what God wanted to
communicate (CCC, nos. 106, 108-114).

DD35B4E3D6DD436C884FE2043B9D78AB.description:
Since God inspired the biblical writers, he is the
author of Scripture (CCC, nos. 105-106, 136).

BC09AD7171104195A1D3832200C221E7.description:
Inspiration is the gift of the Holy Spirit by which
a human author was able to write a biblical book
which really has God as the author and which
teaches faithfully and without error the saving
truth that God willed to be consigned to us for our
salvation (CCC, nos. 105, 135).

F93BA0AC26BD40F88003315D21E31BBB.description:
The Deposit of Faith and the role of the
Church (CCC, nos. 84-95, 98-100).

BB6CB6E5A446479485BAD68947BF583B.description:
The relationship between Tradition and Sacred
Scripture (CCC, nos. 80-83, 97).

2EF696ECE6514FDBB5FFFC892F6C4D8C.description:
The transmission of Divine Revelation (CCC, nos.
74-95).

BC4622019D604EB48BCEEA36BA9AF54B.description:
Jesus Christ, the first and the last, the
definitive Word of Revelation, the one to
whom all Scripture bears witness, is God’s only
Son (CCC, nos. 65-67, 73, 101-104, 134, 423).

0236061A35AB4B78ADC4CFBAF9C2E887.description:
Preparation through John the Baptist
(CCC, nos. 523, 717-720).

92FE27D70EDA4C01926ABEAEF3F423CD.description:
Scripture as a divinely inspired record of God’s
Revelation in history (CCC, nos. 54-64, 70-
72).

1153A56350DB436FA51B0E0A6B6D0AD2.description:
Contemporary arguments based on the human
person’s opening to truth, beauty, moral
goodness, freedom, voice of conscience
(CCC, no. 33).

DF98C80CC9CF4D298D1AC2DE89A71B6C.description:
Vatican I: we can grasp with certainty the
existence of God through human reason
(CCC, nos. 36-38, 46-47).

42381195C299484B91199F5ED5AB1455.description:
St. Thomas Aquinas and the five proofs
for the existence of God.

69EF2B45B16F43DE978C9428A27BE6FD.description:
Scholastic theology’s arguments for the
existence of God (CCC, nos. 31, 34).

93B7591BCFAC4B04BD733D55FFA19395.description:
Old Testament references, including
Genesis and Wisdom.

01D42629E18F4441A47A973B92310BCE.description:
Natural Revelation attested to in Sacred
Scripture (CCC, no. 32).

02E3547AD8DC4816935FB669BE44935A.description:
Only in God can lasting joy and peace be found in
this life and in the next.

9B23EE820ECB4BDFBEB6F739474E1CBB.description:
That longing itself is from God, who desires and
initiates a relationship with each person.

6548F47EC1FE4A8B83CB54A32DA9D0F3.description: Within all people there is a longing for God.

57880C4673DD41AB9787304D274E291B.description:
The thirst and desire for God (Catechism of the Catholic
Church [CCC], nos. 27-30, 44-45, 1718).

E87509C2D26D4BDB934307960150A431.description: How Do We Know About God?
